results.title: Service to the inland
results.creator_credit: J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: A story of the inland telegraph, demonstrating the need for and efficiency of the inland communications system. Shows a message from a Northern Territory bush wireless to Dunlop Tyres translated into a narrative about developments in the outback (transportation, primary industry, the flying doctor etc.). Also includes footage of Aboriginal couriers travelling overland on foot, Aboriginal settlements, their culture, cooking, food gathering etc, in particular Emily’s Gap.

results.title: Wind
results.creator_credit: Ivan Sen, Graeme Isaac, New South Wales Film and Television Office, ABS, SBS Independent and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
1857, The Australian Alps. Jess, a young black tracker and his elderly sergeant discover the body of a gold miner. They track the killer, an old Aboriginal man, to a cabin on a clear plateau. After losing their horse and with the sergeant in bad health they are forced to shelter in a cabin. As Jess falls asleep he is visited in his dreams by the old Aboriginal man. When Jess is faced with executing the old man he is forced to decide his fate, to choose his friend the sergeant, or to follow his ancestral soul. Cast includes Ralph Cotterill, Bradley Byqar and Steve Dodd.

results.title: Saturday night: Sunday morning [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Rima Tamou, Pauline Clague, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission and New South Wales Film and Television Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Based on the Archie Weller short story, this film takes us on a journey into the discontented life of Melanie as she grapples with adolescence, rural isolation and life with her dysfunctional father. Her difficulties escalate when she is taken hostage by three young men for whom life has very little meaning and actions have no consequences. Essentially a rites of passage drama, both Melanie and her captors struggle to come to terms with assumptions of difference, indigenous and non-indigenous race relations, institutionalised injustice, and loss. Cast includes Alyssa McClelland, Peter Browne and Luke Caroll.

results.title: Harry's War
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Richard Frankland, John Foss, ABC-TV (Australia), Film Victoria, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, AFI [au] and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Harry, a Koorie, and Mitch, a non-Aboriginal Australian, are two mates who go off to fight in Papua New Guinea during the Second World War. Harry grows from a boy in uniform to a man in war. We watch as he learns of his impending death and how he faces it. ‘Harry’s War’ is about when mateship transcends race, cultural differences and social barriers. It is a story of how war drives men to the brink and the journey becomes more important than the journey’s end. Cast includes: David Ngoombujarra, Peter Docker, Glenn Shea, Bob Maza and Christina Saunders.

results.title: Malbangka country
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Gustav Malbangka and his family have set up their own community at Gilbert Springs, in the heart of Malbangka country. Gustav talks about his early life, his reasons for leaving Hermannsburg (a Lutheran Mission in Central Australia) and his plans for the future. Shows daily life at Gilbert Springs and a trip to Areyonga. Photography by Geoff Burton. Narrated by Gus Williams.

results.title: Surfing: the healing wave
results.creator_credit: Tim Burns, Huey Benjamin and Neugh Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: Aborigines come from all over Australia to compete in this unique and colorful event - the annual indigenous surfing contest at Fingal on the East Coast. Kyle Slabb, the narrator, is a young aboriginal surfer whose clan are hosting the event. He guides the viewer around the spectacular rivers and idyllic coastal reserves of his homelands, offering insights into traditional ways, dance and ceremony, and an understanding of his struggle to preserve these values in his modern life. The film is a lively and uplifting look at the positive steps taken by an indigenous community as it strives to achieve cultural continuity for future generations.

results.title: Iwerre Atherrame: two paths
results.creator_credit: Kwementyaye (David) Vadiveloo, Australian Film Commission, Victorian College of the Arts and Achilles Heel
results.brief_description: The sometimes cruel but often beautiful landscape of Alice Springs is looked at from a different perspective in this confronting documentary. Focussing on four school children who have been rejected from the mainstream educational system, this film looks at the Detour Project, which is an alternative schooling initiative set up for Aboriginal children who have not benefitted form the education offered in the mainstream system. It offers a curriculum both in Arrente and English, it preserves the traditional language and culture of the people of Alice Springs and recognises the importance of culture, belonging and a sense of place. It is a journey of hope, simply told but with a savage twist.

results.title: Children of the Musgraves
results.creator_credit: Edmee Campbell-Dobbie, J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: Filmed at Ernabella Mission Station in the Musgrave Ranges, 1000 miles north of Adelaide. Shows the life of Aborigines, their schooling and play, and their assimilation to white Australian ways. They are also given time each day to follow their own cultural traditions of hunting and cooking. Narrated by J.J. Hume.

results.title: Moorditji: Australian indigenous cultural expressions (PC & MAC)
results.creator_credit: The Moorditji Consortium, Australian Indigenous Cultural Expressions and Moorditji Consortium
results.brief_description: SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: Windows 95, 98 or 3.1/Mac OS 7.1 or higher. Featuring Aaron Pedersen and Justine Saunders as your guides, this CD Rom showcases the work of more than 100 of Australia’s Indigenous artists. Learn about different artists and aspects of Indigenous culture Australia wide by exploring this well presented and highly informative CD Rom. A tip: This CD Rom contains visual, audio and textual information about many Indigenous artists, some of whom are deceased. If you think these details may be distressing and you would like to hide this information about certain artists, choose the “List of Artists” options in the opening menu. A teacher’s guide accompanies the disc and covers the following areas: introduction; using Moorditji; links with curriculum framework; teaching strategies and terminology, planning a unit of work; general worksheets.

results.title: Up in the sky: Tracey Moffatt in New York
results.creator_credit: Jane Cole and Jane Cole Productions
results.brief_description: This frank and insightful documentary focuses on the work of Australian photographic artist and filmmaker, Tracey Moffat. The film has Moffat discussing her work in her exhibition - Up In The Sky, on the eve of its opening at the prestigious gallery Dia Centre for the Arts, New York, (Oct. 1997) as the first Australian artist to be represented in the gallery. The exhibition housed four bodies of work; Night Cries: A rural tragedy (90), Guapa (95), Heaven (97) and Up In The Sky (97). Other works discussed are; Something More (89) and Scarred for Life (94). The artist provides an understanding to her motivations and techniques employed in the construction of her work.
